thread.title: Crackdown urged as family trust leakage tops $1b
thread.title_full: Crackdown urged as family trust leakage tops $1b | afr.com

author: Joanna Mather
title: Crackdown urged as family trust leakage tops $1b
text:
KPMG says family trusts should be denied a discount on capital gains tax. by Joanna Mather Accounting firm KPMG has recommended family trusts pay full capital gains tax amid fresh estimates that revenue leakage associated with such trusts tops $1 billion a year.
Family trusts are viewed by some as the key way in which wealthy Australians engage in aggressive tax planning.
As such, access to the 50 per cent capital gains tax discount by trusts should be phased out, KPMG says.
Death should also be treated as a "realisation event" for capital gains tax purposes in some circumstances.
This would diminish the ability to pass major wealth across generations untaxed, KPMG says.
Some trusts are very large, such as the Hope Margaret Hancock Trust, which became the subject of a brutal legal battle between Gina Rinehart and some of her children. It is believed to be worth about $5 billion.
Groups such as the Australian Council of Social Service have called for an overhaul of trust law as part of the government's tax review.
Dealing with loopholes They say tax loopholes exploited by the rich should be dealt with before an increase in the goods and services tax, which would hurt poor families the most.
Dale Boccabella, an associate professor of tax law at the University of NSW, estimates lost revenue associated with the use of family trusts easily exceeds $1 billion a year.
He argues the tax treatment of discretionary trusts departs from that of other entities and other taxpayers.
For example, income generated by a family trust can be apportioned to members of the trust who fall into lower income brackets, thus minimising tax payable. While such activity is not illegal, it does not pass the "smell test", Associate Professor Boccabella writes in an article for The Conversation .
For breaches of the law, the Australian Taxation Office has a special "trusts taskforce".
As at January 31, 2015, which are the latest figures available, the taskforce had 21 audits and 397 reviews.
"Seven cases involving serious exploitation of trusts have been escalated for possible law enforcement action and two taxpayers are currently before the courts on serious criminal charges in relation to Trust Taskforce related matters," the ATO website says.
Capital gains ACOSS has recommended that from July next year, tax-preferred income of private discretionary trusts should be taxed as capital gains in the hands of beneficiaries.
There should also be tighter rules to prevent tax avoidance on income, including capital gains, that is not distributed to beneficiaries each year. This would save $1 billion in 2016-17, ACOSS says.
In its wide-ranging submission to the government's tax review, KPMG says if death was to be considered a realisation event for assets held by an individual, there would have to be some exceptions.
These should include where an asset is the family home, farm or small business.
A new type of small business structure is proposed to replicate some of the positive features of the trust model for succession planning.
"It is important to recognise that this proposal is not the instigation of a death duty," the submission says.
"It is merely a partial withdrawal of a rollover currently embedded within our system with the denial of the CGT discount to discretionary trusts."
